titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller Foundation records, projects, SG 1.1, Series 300 Latin America - Series 833 Lebanon
A Guide to the Rockefeller Foundation records, projects, SG 1.1, Series 300 Latin America - Series 833 Lebanon FA386b

did.unittitle: Rockefeller Foundation records, projects, SG 1.1, Series 300 Latin America - Series 833 Lebanon

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The project files are arranged in series according to country. Each country or geographical area was assigned a three-digit number by RF staff. In addition, letters signifying program areas are used: for example, "A" indicates a grant in the Medical Sciences, and "C" Nursing. Material is organized within these letter/program subdivisions alphabetically by grant title. A grant title usually consists of a heading that includes the name of the institution or individual that received the grant. Thus each grant, or project, is filed individually in one or more folders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Types of records include: project files.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Confidential material in this record group has been segregated and is inaccessible. Each pertinent file is open to research, and physical removal of the segregated material within each file is not necessary. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact a RAC archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Rockefeller Foundation has title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of material relating to more than one country in Latin America. Most of the series is composed of files of recipients of Foundation Agricultural Scholarships in the 1950's (300 D).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Four subseries as follows:
300 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
300 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
300 R Humanities and arts
300 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The majority of projects treated in this material are in the medical and natural sciences and date from the 1940's and 1950's. Prominent institutions are the Institute of Biochemical Research, the University of Buenos Aires, the National University of the Litoral, the Institute of Plant Science, and the University of Cordoba. Early files, generated by Foundation officers, include a report by Richard M. Pearce, "Medical Education in Argentina," (1917, 1925) and reports by Nelson C. Davis, Persis Putnum, E. R. Rickard, and R. C. Shannon.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Eight subseries as follows:
301 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
301 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
301 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing.
301 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
301 I Malaria
301 M Respiratory diseases
301 R Humanities and arts
301 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of records dating primarily from 1930 to 1950, mainly documenting Rockefeller Foundation public health programs. "Medical Education in Bolivia" (1926), by Robert A. Lambert, is part of a worldwide investigation of medical education undertaken by the Foundation in the 1920s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Five subseries as follows:
303 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
303 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
303 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
303 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
303 O Yellow fever

did.unittitle: Lam Lambert, Robert A. "Medical Education in Bolivia"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Early Brazilian material (1916-1940) reflects The Rockefeller Foundation's commitment to public health and hygiene, including work to control diseases such as hookworm, malaria, and yellow fever. Yellow fever was a dominant concern of The Foundation in Brazil from 1927 to 1955; the Foundation operated two laboratories in Bahia and Rio de Janeiro. The voluminous yellow fever files contain staff diaries and journals, laboratory diaries, records of surveys and tests, and case histories. Other early grants went to the Sao Paulo Faculty of Medicine and schools of nursing in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. In the 1940s and 1950s agricultural projects became a major concern. During this period, grants to programs in the natural sciences, particularly at the University of Sao Paolo, were also numerous.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Twelve subseries as follows:
305 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
305 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
305 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
305 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
305 H Hookworm
305 I Malaria
305 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
305 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health)
305 O Yellow fever
305 R Humanities and arts
305 S Social sciences
305 V Virus studies

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to original archival material is permitted. Microfilm user copies are open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The only material in Series 309, Chile, dating before the 1930s is a report on medical education, medical relief, and public health (1919) by Richard M. Pearce. Except for a few grants for projects in agriculture, the humanities, and medicine, which were funded in the 1930s, most Foundation support to Chile began in the 1940s and continued into the 1950s. Grants for agricultural and medical research at the University of Chile and the Catholic University predominate; public health projects were also supported.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Eight subseries as follows:
309 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
309 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
309 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
309 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
309 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
309 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
309 R Humanities and arts
309 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Medical education in Colombia received Rockefeller Foundation attention with a general survey by Alan Gregg (1923) and a report by W. M. Monroe on medicine and natural sciences at the National University (1923). The Foundation was also involved in disease control in Colombia, beginning in 1919 with hookworm, 1923 with yellow fever, 1927 with malaria. From 1945 to 1955, most Foundation support went to agriculture research. Material on agriculture is located in 311 as well as in 311 D.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Eleven subseries as follows:
311 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
311 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
311 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
311 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
311 H Hookworm
311 I Malaria
311 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
311 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
311 O Yellow fever
311 R Humanities and arts
311 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In Costa Rica, the Foundation was involved primarily with public health and disease control (malaria, yellow fever, tuberculosis).

arrangement.p: Six subseries as follows:
313 I Malaria
313 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
313 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
313 O Yellow fever
313 R Humanities and arts
313 T Tuberculosis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In the 1920s, The Rockefeller Foundation surveyed medical education in Cuba; The Foundation also supported the University of Havana Medical School. In the 1930s and 1940s the Foundation worked to control malaria and yellow fever.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Five subseries as follows:
315 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
315 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
315 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
315 O Yellow fever
315 R Humanities and arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Material dating primarily from the 1940s concerning nursing education, health services, and libraries comprises the greatest portion of the material in this series. Files devoted to Rockefeller Foundation activity in yellow fever span the years 1918-1956.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Five subseries as follows:
317 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
317 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
317 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
317 O Yellow fever
317 R Humanities and arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These records relate almost solely to public health work in Guatemala in the early 1930s. The files also contain a report on medical education in Guatemala prepared in 1922; this report was part of a worldwide Foundation survey of medical education. In addition, there is material pertaining to a grant to the National Archeological Museum, 1945-1950.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Four subseries as follows:
319 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
319 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
319 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administartion, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
319 R Humanities and arts

did.unittitle: LAM Lambert, Robert A. "Medical Education in Guatamala"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Early material relates to medical education in Haiti and includes a report on medical education which was part of The Rockefeller Foundation's world-wide survey of medical education. Aside from an effort in malaria control, later files (1948-1955) concern the humanities (e.g., libraries, English language teaching, and painting).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The early (1920s) material in these files concerns the medical sciences and includes a report on medical education in Mexico which was part of a world-wide Rockefeller Foundation survey of medical education. Public health related records also begin in the 1920's and continue into the 1940's; these records concern Foundation work with typhoid fever, hookworm, malaria, and health demonstration units.

Records relating to the agricultural program in Mexico span the years from 1933 to 1956, with the bulk of the material dated between 1945 and 1955. In 1943, the Foundation launched its renowned Mexican agricultural program. This program administered by The Rockefeller Foundation, included research by resident Foundation staff to improve Mexico's major food crops; fellowships, scholarships, and travel grants to train Mexican agricultural scientists as well as scientists from other countries; and grants to universities and other institutions to support education and research in agricultural science. The agricultural program records are found in 323, with the exception of institutional grants which are located in 323 D. Additional records of the Foundation agricultural program in Mexico are located in RG 1.2, Series 323.

Files from the 1940s and 1950s also resulted from RF grants to institutions in the areas of medical research and education, the natural sciences (mathematics, chemistry, physics), and the humanities and social sciences (libraries and museums, history and anthropology, music).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Nine subseries as follows:
323 (no program letter, general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
323 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
323 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
323 H Hookworm
323 I Malaria
323 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
323 Q Epidemiological investigations and studies
323 R Humanities and arts
323 S Social sciences

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Additional records of the Foundation agricultural program in Mexico are located in RG 1.2, Series 323.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest files, dealing with medical sciences, include a report (1926) which resulted from The Rockefeller Foundation's world-wide survey of medical education. Some public health material is present, including files relating to the ICA Health Service, the National Institute of Hygiene, malaria and yellow fever. The Foundation made grants in the medical sciences during the 1940s and 1950s to the University of San Marcos in Lima; it also supported agricultural and veterinary research in the 1950s at various institutions including the National School of Agriculture in La Molina and the University of San Marcos at Lima.

scopecontent.p: The majority of material in this series deals with grants to the Institute of Biological Sciences at Montevideo (1941-1925) under the direction of Clemente Estable. There is also a report (1917-1925) on medical education in Uruguay; this report resulted from a world-wide Rockefeller Foundation survey of medical education. did.unittitle: Great Britain - Fellowships, Scholarships, Training Awards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest material in this series documents The Rockefeller Foundation's concern with medical education. Of particular interest are files related to the support of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a report by Richard M. Pearce on medical education in England (1923-1926). Numerous fellowships were awarded to English medical students, especially during and immediately after World War II.

After 1928, the Foundation's activities expanded into the humanities and social sciences. Among the first non-US grants in these areas were grants made to the British Museum, the Bodleian Library (Oxford), and the London School of Economics and Political Science.
Other fields of interest for the Foundation in England include nursing, physics, biochemistry, organic chemistry, and placement of refugee scholars.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Nine subseries as follows:
401 (no program letter, general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
401 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
401 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
401 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
401 E Fellowships, training awards

401 F Declinations (within program, or outside program but receiving more consideration than a flat declination, i.e. request circulated to a number of officers for opinion before declining; outside opinion solicited; considerable correspondence leading to the declination)
401 I Malaria
401 R Humanities and arts
401 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest material in this series treats the Foundation's interest in public health and medical education in the Republic of Ireland, including field units in Counties Cork, Donegal and Kildare. Later areas of interest included physics, nursing, and zoology and the humanities.
Material extending from 1950 to 1972 consists entirely of a historical record of the activities of the Irish Folklore Institute.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Eight subseries as follows:
403 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
403 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
403 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
403 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
403 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
403 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
403 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health)
403 R Humanities and arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Early Rockefeller Foundation grants to Australia were made both in medical education and anthropological research. Between 1929 and 1961 the Foundation sponsored a series of fellowships in the social sciences. The foundation also funded an important survey of the humanities in Australia between 1945 and 1947.

410 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
410 E Fellowships, scholarships, training awards
410 ES Social science fellows
410 R Humanities and arts
410 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most of the material in this series covers the public health activities of S. M. Lambert, the Rockefeller Foundation officer assigned to the South Pacific between 1923 and 1939. Of key importance was the founding of the Central Medical School of Suva, Fiji, which trained native medical practitioners.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Three subseries as follows:
419 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area.)
419 L Public health demonstrations, local health units
419 T Tuberculosis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The first Foundation grant to Canada was as part of a relief effort in Newfoundland (1914). As part of regular program-oriented support, the Foundation supported various medical and public health projects, especially between 1920 and 1950. Dalhousie and McGill University, the Universities of Manitoba and Montreal, and various Provincial governments were the main beneficiaries of the Foundation's interests in these areas.

In the humanities, the Foundation gave grants for folklore studies, library surveys, and drama, mainly in the 1940s. Support for the social sciences came mainly through grants and fellowships administered by the Canadian social Science Research Council (1940-1957) and various universities.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Ten subseries as follows:
427 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
427 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
427 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
427 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
427 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
427 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
427 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health)
427 R Humanities and arts
427 S Social sciences
427 T Tuberculosis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest Foundation grants to Jamaica were made as part of its programs against hookworm disease and malaria and for development of public health facilities. The largest amount of Foundation activity here, however, was in the area of tuberculosis control (1931-1941). This series contains considerable material on that subject, including narrative and statistical reports and records of an x-ray unit funded by the Foundation.

437 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
437 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health)
437 R Humanities and arts
437 T Tuberculosis
437 U Yaws

scopecontent.p: Early material in this series deals with a grant to the Imperial College of Tropical Diseases (1924-1933). Most of the files in this series document the Foundation's activity in virus disease research on these islands (1952-1972).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest Foundation grant to India (1913) was made to the All-India School of Hygiene and Public Health at Calcutta. This school continued to be the major institutional recipient of Foundation aid in the areas of public health and medical education until 1950.
Of particular interest in this series is a 30 volume manuscript survey and history of medical education in India by W. S. Carter (1926-1927).

During the 1930s and 1940s the Foundation supported various rural health programs, developmental aid to nursing, and a survey of librarianship during this period. From 1951 to 1971 the Foundation's main interest in India was expressed through its virus disease research program. Researchers should note that material covering virus research is filed under both 464 and 464 V.

The Foundation also funded public health and anti-malaria work in the independent Indian states of Mysore (464.1), Sawantwadi (464.4), and Travancore (464.5) from 1928 to 1944. After Indian independence in 1947, these numerical designations were dropped from the Foundation's classification scheme.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Rockefeller Foundation first gave attention to this area as part of its worldwide survey of medical education. From 1928 until 1950, the Foundation also funded projects in hookworm and malaria control, public sanitation, and museum training. Included in these records are correspondence, reports, and a diary by J. Austin Kerr (1944-1946).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The main bulk of the material in this series documents the Rockefeller Foundation's important program to combat yellow fever. The Foundation, through its West African Yellow Fever Commission, maintained research laboratories at Lagos, Nigeria, and field offices throughout the region. These records contain correspondence, reports, a diary by the Commission's director, Henry Beeuwkes (1925-1934), and a set of case histories and medical records of yellow fever victims (1924-1930).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Grants to French institutions were made primarily in the medical sciences field. The earliest grants were awarded for the campaign against tuberculosis, from which the Foundation's nursing program was created. The University of Paris was the major recipient of grants for the medical sciences. Funds were given for work by Theophile Alajouanine, Jean Scherrer, and Clovis Vincent in neurology and neurosurgery and by Georges Heuyer in psychiatry. Funding was given to the Radium Institute in the 1920s, 1930s, and 1940s. The University of Lyons and the University of Strasbourg were also recipients of a relatively large number of medical sciences grants. In addition, there are files dealing with the Pearce report on French medical education which was part of a report on medical education throughout the world.

The Rockefeller Foundation also gave funding to a full range of humanities and social sciences programs. A large number of grants were given for work in philosophy. Grants were also given for a broad range of studies including art history and geography and ethnology. A number of humanities and social sciences grants were made to refugee scholars, including Richard Alewyn (German Literature), Elias Bickermann (Greek archaeology), Kurt Sachs (music history), Julius Lewy (Assyriology), and Paul Schrecker (Philosophy).
The American Library in Paris and the Bibliotheque Nationale also received Foundation support.

500 J Public health demonstrations, local health units

500 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health)
500 O Yellow fever
500 P Undulant fever
500 R Humanities and arts
500 S Social sciences
500 T Tuberculosis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest records of this series (1906-1910) are reports on education in the Far East, particularly in India, China, and Japan, examining the possibilities of establishing western educational systems there. Records from the 1930s-1940s report on the schools that were established, including the Peking Union Medical College, and the effect of medical education on Far Eastern demography. There is also material relating to the American Schools of Oriental Research in Bagdad and Jerusalem.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: From 1913 to 1928 the Foundation's interests in China were directed by the China Medical Board, a division of the foundation. In 1928 the China Medical Board was separately incorporated and the functions continued by the Foundation were transferred to the Foundation's Division of Medical Education. Series 601 contains material after 1928, except for the Historical Records, which go back to 1913. Although the bulk of the material originated before 1945, there is also correspondence as late as 1960. The material consists of correspondence, memos, and reports relating to specific grants, and reports of a general nature which are filed in the 601 (General) section. A section on program and policy contains administrative and policy information in various forms.

Major areas of interest were agriculture and rural economics, public health and medicine. Grants were made predominantly to hospitals, universities and institutes of research. Of special interest are the files on rural reconstruction, the Mass Education movement, and the Peking Union Medical College.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Access to original archival material is permitted. Microfilm user copies are open for research.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: For a more complete view of the Rockefeller Foundation's program in China the records of the Foundation's China Medical Board, Record Group 4, and of the China Medical Board, Inc. Collection should be consulted. Correspondence and reports can also be found in the Foundation's General Correspondence files, Record Group 2.
See also - Record Group 6.1 Field Office-Paris.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most of the material in this series relates to the development of medical sciences and natural sciences, generally through visiting professor grants, public health, and nursing. Institutions receiving aid include the Tokyo Institute of Public Health, Keio University, St. Luke's International Hospital, and the Tohoku Imperial University. There is also a 1921 report on medical education in Japan, part of the Rockefeller Foundation's worldwide survey of medical education, and a survey of medical education after World War II.

609 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
609 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
609 E Fellowships, scholarships, training awards
609 R Humanities and arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most of this series contains material relating to medical and natural sciences during the 1930s - 1940s. Prominent institutionds are the University of Amsterdam, the University of Groningen, the University of Leiden, and the University of Utrecht. Projects included the University of Leiden Observatory, travel grants, and malaria. In the 1940s, Foundation aid to the social sciences and humanities increased, giving grants to museums, libraries, Far Eastern Studies, and economics.

650 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
650 I Malaria
650 R Humanities and arts
650 S Social sciences

scopecontent.p: The material dealing with The Rockefeller Foundation's activities in Yugoslavia covers nine subject areas. There is a concentration of material in medical science (1920-1954), which covers grants to universities, a report of medical education in Yugoslavia, visits by scholars and educators, and public health. There is also material on nursing (1920-1950) and nursing schools, as well as a report by F. Elisabeth Crowell.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material documenting the Rockefeller Foundation's activities in Germany is concentrated in Medical Sciences, including research grants (1922-1950) to institutions and individuals, reports on medical education and medical literature in Germany, and Natural Science grants to institutions and specific persons. Of particular interest in the General subseries are Surveys of Postwar Germany by Robert J. Havighurst and Albert R. Mann, including supplements, diaries, and preliminary material.

717 R Humanities and arts
717 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records on Hungary document Foundation activity that almost exclusively related to medicine and public health. The University of Budapest received an extensive number of grants in such fields as pediatric medicine, pharmacology, physiology, and nursing. There is a file covering the work in biochemistry of Albert Szent-Gyorgyi, 1937 winner of the Nobel Prize in medicine and physiology. In the field of public health, the Foundation helped set up local health departments in Godollo, Mezokovesd, Pecs, and Vac. There is also a grant, which ran from 1927 through 1931, to the State Hygienic Institute for a study on influenza.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Ten subseries as follows:
750 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
750 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
750 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
750 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
750 E Fellowships, scholarships, training awards
750 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
750 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
750 L Public health education (schools of hygiene and public health
750 M Respiratory diseases
750 S Social sciences

scopecontent.p: This material is concentrated in the 1930s and 1940s. Included is a Public Health Survey of 1949. There are a number of universities that the Rockefeller Foundation gave grants to covering the field of medical science (1920-1957). There are also reports by F. Elizabeth Crowell on nursing (1922, 1924), material dealing with natural science grants to universities, and reports on malaria.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The files for Foundation grants in Portugal all document health-related activities. Files for public health projects include material on the Lisbon Health Center. In addition, there are files showing Foundation support for a nursing school and for work on the eradication of malaria. Material documenting biomedical research includes files for grants in biochemistry and histology and embryology.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The files for Rockefeller Foundation activity in Rumania show a very strong involvement in medical, public health, and nursing projects. Grants were made for medical research in anatomy and physiology. Projects were funded for the eradication of scarlet fever and malaria, for the work of the Cluj Institute of Hygiene and the Institute of Hygiene in Bucharest, and for various local health department activities and public health demonstrations. The Bucharest and Cluj schools of nursing also received grants, the latter for public health nursing. There were also grants for work in psychology at the University of Cluj and for the Roumanian Institute of Social Science.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rockefeller Foundation activity in Poland, as documented in these records, involved primarily the funding of biomedical research work, public health programs, and nursing. Biomedical research was funded at the Universities of Cracow, Lodz, Warsaw, and Wroclaw in such fields as neurology and neurosurgery, pathology, pediatrics, and physiology. Public health projects were funded in Bendzin, Lwow, Makotow, Skierniewice, Vilno, and Warszawa. Nursing programs were funded at the University of Cracow, for public health and bedside nursing, and at the Warsaw School of Nursing. There is a file on Richard M. Pearce's report on "Medical Education in Poland," which was part of a survey of medical education throughout the world.
There is a small amount of material relating to grants in the social sciences, especially for economics studies.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Eight subseries as follows:
789 (no program letter; general material which does not fit into a particular program area)
789 A Medical sciences (research conducted in medical schools or medical research institutes, research directly applicable to the mental and physical health of human beings)
789 C Nursing (nursing education, public health nursing)
789 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
789 J Public health demonstrations, local health units
789 K Health services (epidemiology, reform, public health administration, laboratories, vital statistics, and particularly sanitary engineering)
789 R Humanities and arts
789 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The records relating to Foundation activity in Spain deal almost exclusively with public health matters. There are files documenting projects on eradication of hookworm in mines, the campaign against malaria, and the development of a Bureau of Sanitary Statistics and an Epidemiological Bureau. Public Health demonstration projects were started in Albacete, Caceres, and Vallecas. There are also files concerning an anti-smallpox campaign and the development of public health nursing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Rockefeller Foundation's interest in Sweden began in the mid-1920s but grants were not awarded until the 1930s. The major portion of the grants were distributed through four of Sweden's research institutions, especially the Karolinska Institute and the University of Stockholm. Grants were concentrated in the medical sciences and natural sciences. A large portion of these grants were made to support scientists who were forced to flee the political upheaval in Europe from the mid-1930s through the post-war years.

800 D Natural sciences and agriculture (research usually conducted in departments outside of medical schools, research in pure science, veterinary medicine or agriculture)
800 R Humanities and arts
800 S Social sciences

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The earliest files in this series relate to medical schools in Switzerland, part of the Rockefeller Foundation's worldwide study of medical education in the 1920s. Later grants to the Universities of Basel, Berne, Geneva and Zurich deal mostly with purchase of equipment for research in the natural sciences. Material from the later 1940s and 1950s primarily documents travel grants.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Early Foundation interest in Turkey came in the areas of medical education and nursing. Grants were made in the 1920s and 1930s for various public health projects in Ankara and Istanbul. Support in the later 1940s came for a survey of nursing and a travel grant for a lecturer in economics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Rockefeller Foundation's earliest activity in Israel (formerly Palestine) was in the fields of malaria and hookworm control. During the 1930s, the Foundation also sponsored refugee scholars who were placed on the faculty of Hebrew University. Later grants were made in the fields of jaundice research and sex research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With the exception of a few general reports on medical education, the Rockefeller Foundation's interest was channelled entirely through the American University of Beirut. The Foundation gave support to the University's Medical School (1920-1967), to its Arabic Studies program (1948-1953) and School of Nursing (1927-1941). Although the files contain considerable material concerning the University's Department of Sociology, including a textbook and yearbooks, there is no record of any Foundation grant for its support during this period.

833 R Humanities and arts
833 S Social sciences
